sn24.71:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.71:4.3: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.71:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.71:5.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.71:5.2: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.71:5.7: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.71:5.8: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.71:5.10: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.71:5.12: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.71:5.14: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn24.71:5.15: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn24.71:5.22: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.71:5.24: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn24.71:5.25: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn24.71:6.1: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn24.71:6.3: You should truly see any kind of feeling …
sn24.71:6.6: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn24.71:7.2: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
